Reviews.Title: Great Camera with a few small issues
Reviews.Author: Howard "Howie"
Reviews.Content: So I was in the market for a new camera and I wanted a tough camera because well cell phones these days who really needs a basic point and shoot camera and also I Scuba Dive and previously had a Canon Elph with a waterproof enclosure.  Every time I would take it in the water I had a moment where I crossed my fingers and hoped the case wouldn't leak.  With the recent 2013 model releases I narrowed it down to the Nikon AW110 and the Panasonic Lumix TS5.  I finally decided to go with the Lumix TS5 for 1 major reason.  Panasonic sells an external enclosure in case you plan on going deeper then 43 feet. (not on the market yet but I plan on getting one)I had read a lot of mix reviews on the TS4 about leaking which made me a bit nervous but I'm going to hope and assume they have rectified all the issues with the TS5.  I've had the camera about a week now.  I'm going to start off with a few negatives for me first (these are mostly pet peeves).Negatives:1.  What is the deal with the battery charger?  Why Panasonic didn't build the charger prongs into the charger is beyond me.  Now you need to carry around a charger plus a cable to plug into the charger and the wall.2. The manual states you can't keep the camera under water more then 60 minutes, that is not listed anywhere on their website would have been nice to know prior to purchasing.3. The manual states, if you drop the camera and then it leaks its not covered under warranty.  Um isn't the point of a tough camera so it can be dropped?  Why is that voiding the warranty?4.  My biggest complaint though is this proprietary connector they use to connect to your computer (hello micro usb standard Panasonic?), also the connector looks almost identical to the micro HDMI slot) so you gotta pay attention to make sure your putting it in the correct slot because their smaller connector cable sort of fits in the micro hdmi port. (made that mistake by accident already once)Positives:1.  The picture quality seems very good.  While I have only used the camera twice so far most of the pictures came out great.  I took the camera to a concert the other day, being very dark I was concerned how the pictures would show up. The camera has a feature called Hand Held Night Mode, and it basically took a bunch of shots in a row and I'm guessing merged them together so the final photo was actually good looking.  I had the camera on auto made and it automatically selected this.2.  The zoom is decent at 4.6X and adding the digital zoom up to 9.3X I had no issues getting a clear shot (even when it was dark).3.  The NFC is a nice feature as I own an Android phone and all you need to do is tap the phone and the camera together to pair them.  You have to install the Panasonic App, but you can do a bunch of things with it.  Remote control the camera, copy photos from the camera to the phone etc. (**disclaimer** occasionally I've had issues with the pairing on my HTC EVO LTE)4. The video recording and sound is great.  I record a 30 second clip while at the concert the other day and it was very clear and the picture looked great (from no zoom to fully zoomed).5. Had no problems catching moving objects and even with my shaky hands the pictures came out un-blurred.Miscellaneous:On a side note I needed to confirm some things with Panasonic the manual stated, Panasonic Tier 1 support is worthless, finally escalated to Tier 2 and they were a lot more helpful.1.  The camera has a rattling noise when it is off.  Panasonic's response was: This is normal.  The camera contains an Optical Image Stabilizer.  When turned on the optical image stabilizer is engaged and thereby compensates for hand shake or camera movement.  However, when it the camera is turned off the Optical Image Stabilizer is disengaged and allows movement of those components.  This is the rattling or clicking that you hear.2.  The manual says "do not use for Scuba Diving" I wanted to confirm if that meant at any depth or in general.  Their response was: Recreational Scuba diving goes to ~120 ft.  We included this statement due to the camera's depth limitation.3. The manual says "Waterproof function of the camera is for sea water and fresh water only."  I wanted the make sure I could take the camera in the pool.  Their response was: You can use it in a pool, which is fresh water.  We included this statement as it cannot be used in hot tubs (due to high temp) or used as an inspection camera in hazardous situations such as polluted water, chemical spills and so on.I have not yet taken the camera in the water or dropped it or used it as a "tough" camera so I can't really comment on any of that, hopefully I can update this review as I use it over the course of the next few months.  But for now I will give it 5 stars as it hasn't shown me any reason to rate it lower just yet.

Reviews.Title: great features-unusual set up
Reviews.Author: R. Chadwick "robchad67"
Reviews.Content: First this is a great camera and a pretty reasonable price. The included features are fun and certainly creative.Going to just put some thoughts down- positive and negative 1. Very slippery grip and I would purchase a floating grip. My last underwater camera was an Optio WG-1. Very different shape and that camera was surrounded by a non-skd type grip. Thisonly has them on either side. ( but is is comfortable )2. The "manual mode is almost manual. I assumed that i could adjust aperture and shutter at my discretion. This only has two apertures available F3.3 and F10. The shutter speed is from fractions of a second to 4". I guess i was expecting DSLR manual. so milky waterfall scenes "could" get done- more playing with the exposure value- which can be done With Bracketing for you HDR fans ( still useful )3. For the time lapse you can adjust the intervals from 10/20/30/40/50/60 seconds ( nothing  else ) and then by the minute for up to 30 minutes with up to 1000 shots. ( unsure about this - to make nice cloudscapes you not only have to drag the shutter you have to keep a tighter interval then 10 second---but still fun! )4. During TIME LAPSE the max open shutter speed is 4 seconds, I guess i was going to try some backyard astrophotography like my d7000 and show the rotation of the circumpolar stars but 4 seconds is really not enough to get the fainter details. Generally i use high aperture 1.8 and 30 seconds for milky way type shots ( still interesting and while not art is it fun )5.Creative filters are fun and interesting. ( Beats trying to post edit them someplace when in-camera works great! )6. Very fast autofocus and the IQ is very good! scene modes are fun and HDR is very good. ( can i keep saying this is a fun camera ? )7. Starry skies scene mode -unlike above #4, is a long term open shutter 15 or 30 seconds-fixed. I can see this being useful for fireworks also. ( to cloudy to get a lot of use lately )8. Stupid double buttom "menu/set". To access you must double click. This is just a gripe coming from a dlsr. My Optio was similar. ( just need to get used to using it )9. NFC and wifi --well wifi works well but i cannot get app to work on iPhone--but works great on my daughters galaxy note. and no NFC for iPhone ( so just move along nothing to see folks )10. The most important---most important button is the lower right "trash can/Q menu". While shooting in any mode and any scene pressing this will pull up a nice graphic interface of what is available for you to use or adjust. This is the creative side that we use when in other than program mode! White balance-ISO-mp size-video settings-burst mode ( up to 60 fps!- reduces mp size )11. This has a dozen different video sizes and formats avchd and mp4 1080 i,p,g,- 720 same with 60 fps!! going to get twixtor and try some things plus a few old school web type 640x480 ( really ? )12. Zoom is quick and quiet but i wont use digital zoom on any camera as it only degrades the quality--BUT this has a nice intelligent zoom that seems ok so far.13. Lastly for now, this is a very nice camera and while it doesn't have everything i wanted- i can drop it and throw it in the river and it still take great pics. Macro with 1 led light was ok but not at good as my Optio, but the wireless fun, greature aperture and shutter speed with options make up for it. Amazon was great with upgraded shipping and the price was good. Compared many cameras and while the nikon was close ( 240 fps slo mo )the wider aperture and better than most controls were a good selling point fo me. Thanks for reading

Reviews.Title: This is a fun camera to use. Great and easy to use features that puts the Panasonic DMC TS-5 above the rest.
Reviews.Author: WIM

} } } Length:: 1:57 MinsThe Video is from a group of still pictures using the time lapse picture option. Then with the camera in the review,menu option you can create a time lapse video and select a group of time lapse photos. You can edit or remove each of the pictures prior to editing. Once a time lapse video is created you will have all of the still pictures as well as the newly created video. Very cool feature!I bought this camera after mine broke on my first day of vacation. I wanted a tough, waterproof camera and this TS-5 was the best that I found after comparing it to several other waterproof cameras. This TS-5 had a larger battery, which allowed 340 pictures on a charge and that is about 100 more then the closest similar camera. By the way I bought additional batteries (http://www.amazon.com/dp/B00CIVVT04/ref=pe_175190_21431760_3p_M3T1_ST1_dp_1) that allowed me to take 700 pictures on a charge.This camera has a time lapse option that s a great feature when used with a tripod. You have several options such as 10 second intervals up to 30 minutes to take pictures of the changing sky or a blooming flower etc. once you have set and taken time lapse photos the camera has an option to convert it to a movie at 6 frames per second or 30 fps to create a seamless movie from the still pictures.There is also a feature that will allow you, while reviewing video that you have already recorded, to save/convert any frame to a still picture. This will also keep the newly created still picture in perfect focus. I recorded a bird drinking and flying off and was able to create still pictures of it taking flight. This was a very cool effect and is simple to use.I would recommend a tripod to use some of these options. I bought a flexible tripod, which allowed me to wrap the legs in a small tree and use the remote control function to take video of a birds nest feeding new born chicks. I found myself keeping the camera with me all the time to try to get familiar with the functions and I had a lot of fun doing it.This camera was the only one that has built in WIFI. The remote control function uses this feature. The camera generates its own wifi signal and you just have to connect your tablet, I-Pad, I-Phone or other smart phone to that SSID wifi network, did use a I-Pad and an I-Phone 4s and each worked fine. You do have to download the free Panasonic app to use this feature. With the remote control function you can take video, still pic's and zoom. You can also review still pictures only with this, not video, as well as drag and drop them to save them on your smart phone or tablet. You can setup a link to apps like Facebook and send them right from the camera if you setup a Lumix Club account (free) and it will create a Lumix folder for uploads to Facebook and other apps.Once you have connected to your own wifi setting you can go to the wifi history and rename that setting and save it as a favorite connection, this will remember your network SSID and password and connect quickly without having to re-enter your password, which can be a pain if you do this a lot. With the wifi you can automatically save pictures to your connected device as you take each picture. You can also use this to send pics to your pc without having to connect your camera or remove the mem card. However this did not work with my IMac, nor does the software that comes with the camera work on a Mac. This was not an issue for me as I did open the camera and put the mem card into the Mac and copied all pics that way.The GPS, Altimeter,depth gauge and compass features are also very cool, but I have not used all of them yet. The camera can use the GPS to tag your city and your pictures. I have not been on a vacation to take advantage of this, but I am looking forward to trying it out in a remote setting.This camera has a bunch of preset settings for different situations such as night time shots, pictures through glass, far off scenery etc. it also has an automatic setting that will automatically change according to each situation to take a great pictures. The camera powers up very fast, about 3 seconds so you can shut it off to save the battery and turn it on quickly to take fast shots. You can use burst shooting to take several frames with one push of the shutter button to make the best picture out of the many frames used. This camera focus quickly as well.I haven't even used this under water yet and I absolutely love this camera. Is has these great features plus it is a waterproof (up to 43 feet), shock proof (for a drop up to 6 feet), dust proof and freeze proof and a rugged tough camera.I would recommend extra batteries, a hard case, a tripod and a floating strap in case you drop it in the ocean. As some other reviewers stated you may want to use the heavy or thick part of the strap instead of the thin string to attach your strap to the camera.

Reviews.Title: Before buying this read the customer experience with the TS4 mine follows
Reviews.Author: Michael "SnapDoc"
Reviews.Content: Let me start by saying that I am a photographer. I buy cameras all the time. I buy them for myself my family and recommend them for my friends. I love to do the research and usually enjoy the results. This camera came highly recommended by reliable sources(DPreview etc) and I purchased it 15 months ago. I bought this camera to serve a specific role as the go anywhere, not worry about camera that I could give to my six-year-old. It was for vacation swimming and snorkeling as well as winter skiing when it was extremely cold and other cameras wouldn't work. It served those purposes well during its first year. It gave decent pictures. It's GPS function was reliable. It was problem free and gave good underwater pictures as well. I followed the recommendations about maintenance for the camera's battery and memory card door (yes I read directions). I have a Nikonos film underwater camera. Yes I am old, but I understand the care and maintenance that's required for cameras that you take underwater.Last week while vacationing in Hawaii, snorkeling in shallow water we encountered a pod of dolphins. They were playfully all around us. A fantastic photo op. It was at that moment that my Lumix failed. The screen became multicolored lines without a discernible image and I could not capture an image. The day was partially saved by my wife's Canon S 95. She was able to capture some of the action from topsides.I researched this online and found that many owners had this problem and that Panasonic had recommended that after year you buy an expensive kit from them to recondition the door seal or send the camera to them and for a very significant fee they would do that repair/Maintenance.This is not mentioned in their owners manual nor did I receive an email or written product advisory. Now I have an expensive bronze colored paperweight. Based on the reviews Panasonic has not done anything for all of those customers whose cameras failed in this fashion.So sorry Panasonic but I will not be buying any more of your products. This is not how you treat customers. You are not Apple we have lots of other choices for the products that you make.

Reviews.Title: Horrible Customer Service, Mediocre Camera
Reviews.Author: Matt S.
Reviews.Content: To make this easier for all reader formats, I will put the quick version at the top and argue the matter below it:Cons: 1)I have owned two Panasonic cameras that were supposed to be rugged and waterproof, and neither were.  Both failed in less than 1 year, both with less than 3 exposures to water.2) Their customer service is horrible.  I have spent many calls trying to work with them to fix my cameras, and they have some of the worst customer service I have had in years, maybe even my whole life.3) Expensive to maintain the waterproofing.4) Bad warrantyPros: 1) Pictures are fine.  You could get better image quality (pictures and video) with a less expensive camera though.2) My wife likes the outside color :)Further details: I consider myself an amateur photographer.  I usually shoot landscape photography and portraiture.  I ski, snowboard, snorkel and SCUBA dive (not all at the same time).  So it just makes sense to buy a camera that is compact and waterproof for some of these activities.  Years ago, you would buy a camera and waterproof housing.  The O-rings would eventually fail on the housings, especially if they were not cleaned and lubricated.  Most large camera makers now offer an "all-in-one" option.  I knew of a few friends who had the Panasonic Lumix and based on their testimonial and some online research, decided to buy into this product line.For the same purchase price, it is a fact that you can buy another camera that is not made to be "weatherproof" that provides better photo and video quality.  This matters if you do not use the camera by water or around harsh conditions.  If you only use it during nice weather and on land, stop reading and buy something else!!!  If you read Digital Photo magazine, August 2013, it lists its top 5 underwater cameras.  Panasonic does not make the list.  Not in the top 5!!  Canon, Fujifilm, Nikon, Olympus, Pentax.  No Panasonic.  Tells me Panasonic is doing something wrong.By personal experience, the one I bought was taken on a few snorkeling trips.  With the 3rd exposure to water, in less than 5 feet of water, its water seals failed.  The camera never turned back on.  My wife was upset that she couldn't take pictures the rest of the trip.  We had to send the camera back to Panasonic for repair.  In their warranty contract, they can repair the camera with refurbished parts, or just send you back a refurbished camera.  Whatever they decide, you have no choice.  So, they sent us back a refurbished one.We went on our next vacation 6 months later.  1st time this camera was put in the water it failed.  Let me repeat that, 1st time.  In under 20 feet of water.  It is rated to be waterproof much lower than that.  Called customer service multiple times.  Come to find out they only warranty their replacements for 3 months.  It doesn't provoke consumer confidence when a product that should be "good as new" is only warrantied for 3 months.  Because ours is outside of that, they want me to agree to ship it to them and pay for whatever they find is wrong.  No joke, I talked to a supervisor at customer service, she said, "we will send you a shipping label if you agree to repair your camera for a charge."  I said, "What is the charge?"  Her reply, "We will have to inspect it 1st.  You have to agree to pay the charge, whatever it is when we determine it, before we will send you a shipping label.  Do you want me to send the shipping label?"  After three calls and two hours on the phone, that is the best customer service they had to offer.  The first time I called, I spoke with a very reasonable guy, however, the statements and promises he made were later cancelled by another supervisor, and they never called to tell me.Lastly, as you will read in other reviews, it costs a lot to maintain the cameras waterproof rating.  If you are lucky enough to have your camera last 1 year, you have to shell out the cash to have the seals replaced.  You would be foolish to do it yourself, but you can try.Overall, If you have read this far, please just buy another camera.  How many reviews have I written in the past 5 years.... 2.  Why two?  Because I don't want people to have the same experience with a substandard product.  You work hard for your money.  Spend it on something that has a better track record.  Enjoy your vacation without worry.

Reviews.Title: When it's good, it's great, but must of the time it's barely ok.
Reviews.Author: Rolland Waters
Reviews.Content: I had the TS2 version of this camera. This camera, despite the advance in time, is not  only not a better camera but has regressed in several key areas.The three redeeming features of this camera:1.) the new coating on the lens is simply awesome; the old one was good but this one seems to shed almost everything!2.) when it decides to take a good, sharp picture, it takes a great sharp picture with excellent color rendition.3.) it really is waterproof.The rest of the reality:The battery life is execrable. Unless you're going to charge it every single day, you have to turn off GPS and the other features that distinguish this from the TS2. Even then, it's a hundred or so shots before recharging rather than 300-400 for the TS2. But of course the charger from the TS2 doesn't fit so you can't even leave your old charger in the car.The continued use of special-connectors is inexcusable, and fact that it's different special connectors than the TS2 is even more inexcusable.The UI went from good to atrocious. For example, you can't actually turn off the digital zoom; turning it "off" simply means that it pauses at the end of the optical zoom before digitally zooming. So you have to look at the UI rather than just holding down the zoom button. Sigh.The picture quality runs the gamut from incredibly impressive to the appalling, and alas many of the ones you really want to come out are on the appalling end of the scale. For me I think the primary issue is the image stabilization: the exposure is decent, the focus is best at the image point, but the image itself is so soft as to look like an old-school print enlargement.I'd put up with all of this if the average image quality was as good or better as the TS2. But really, the percentage of pictures that come out great is significantly lower than with the TS2.Finally, for those concerned about internal condensation: it does happen. Burying it in rice is one approach, but I find leaving it open in the freezer for a few days works great and doesn't have the risk of rice dust.

Reviews.Title: Unacceptable noise in video
Reviews.Author: Aaron Cohen
Reviews.Content: I purchased this camera due in large part to the issues with noise when recording video I keep reading about with the Olympus TG-2.  Well, the video on my TS5 is unacceptable.  I could care less how the video looks (it looks great) because the noise is incredibly irritating.  This is present both when playing back on my camera as well as on my television.  There are steady repeating grinding noises when taking a video in my room by myself with no ambient noise...Pictures look fine but the video is a dealbreaker.  I don't understand why my 7 year old standard Sony digital camera as well as my 4 year old Olympus waterproof camera do fine with video but this has a grinding noise when recording..  What is the deal with this and the Olympus and sound in their recording feature?

Reviews.Title: Panasonic Lumix DMC-TS5 - TOUGH WATERPROOF Point & Shoot (GREAT piece of engineering)
Reviews.Author: JayHutch
Reviews.Content: If your looking for one of the new tough waterproof PAS cameras you may be paralyzed by all the choices and features. You'll search the web, make the comparisons and hopefully NOT choose the least expensive . . . or most expensive. Still a LOT of choices and its hard to decide. You need to narrow them down. As an avid Nikon digital photog, I understand most of the important features one looks for in a camera, but still had to narrow down the tough waterproof PAS choices somehow.The Nikon looked a little too delicate, but its not. The Canon D20 is a great camera, but I'm not a Canon fan. I wanted full 1080p HD video @ 60 fps. I wanted the best lens system possible. Super fast lens (low aperture) in low light isn't as important as it used to be wit the new technology, so I wanted about 5x zoom. Didn't care about the additional 5x DIGITAL zoom on the TS5, but honestly in "intelligent" zoom setting it works way beyond my expectations. This Lumix TS5 has a Leica lens system. Pixel resolution is so high on most all of them, its enough for anyone @ 12 megapixels. The Lumix TS5 has 16.1. Like I said, that's higher resolution than you'll ever need. Good anti shake technology is important with these small tough cameras you take out into the field. I am amazed at what you can keep sharp handheld with this camera.All things equal. Narrow down the choices to 3 or 4. Make sure your most important features are included, and then get the one with the most NEW features on top of those. The one's your not sure about, because chances are they are worthwhile. Read the reviews and then go back to your comparison pages and bring up all the features side by side. You'll be amazed at some of the new features such as true HDR, and low light capability via multiple automatic exposures blended together seamlessly and staying sharp.Pro's: 1) The low light capability is amazing 2) the anti-shake system exceeds my expectations 3) The Panorama mode is terrific. Naturally on the camera screen its simply a long narrow shot very hard to see. What is great it has a "play" feature and places back the panorama shot like a video. Very cool. Maybe all of then do so - not sure. 4) the video quality in FULL 1080p HD video is also amazing. This is a little PAS camera that can do this? HD video in AVCHD or choose MP4. Vid quality is much better in AVCHD, but unless you have a Mac running OSX Mavericks, your system likely will choke on AVCHD if you want to transfer and play the video's on a PC. My iMac & Macbook can play AVCHD with a few mac tricks, or VLC will handle them for you. 5) Full GPS. Not for navigation, but for geotagging your photos & video's if you wanna. You can turn it on and off at will to conserve battery power. 6) Too many positives to go any further. You'll like the camera. I didn't really care much, but it also comes in black, gray, orange & blue.Con's: 1) Lack of availability of optional accessories. Try to find an OEM Micro HDMI to standard HDMI so you can play back direct from camera to your HDTV. They can't be found. I bought a $7 including shipping micro HDMI to HDMI cable that does the trick & works exactly as it should. 2) The "manual" settings are very limited, but how much are you actually going to need that with a PAS that has so many awesome automatic features? 3) The WiFi is a little tricky to get setup, and doesn't really work as I expected, but it does work. It's easier, and faster, to simply remove the SDHC card and transfer the files that way. 4) It comes with a smallish charger, but with a BIG AC cable that plugs into the side. I'd like to see a fold out plug type to keep the size down in your backpack and do away with the big AC cable. 5) I'm sure I'll get used to the lens it the upper left, rather than the middle of the case, but I've adjusted my grip.Last - DON'T FORGET to buy as big and fast SDHC card as possible and an extra battery. I was able to find a 64 GB Sony SDXC Class 10 card (40 MB/s) for $35 & a 2 pack of batteries with an extra small charger from Big Mike's for another $26.All in all, once you do your homework you will be very happy with any of the top 5 tough waterproof PAS's. I'm pretty sure if you choose the Lumix TS5 you will be tickled pink. I'd give it 5 stars if the accessories were available, and the WiFi worked as expected. You simply can't go wrong with the Panasonic Lumix TS5. Thumbs way up.

Reviews.Title: Worked well until it filled with water after 7 days despite following all instructions including keeping cover closed AND locked
Reviews.Author: Patti Holman
Reviews.Content: The camera was well rated and took great photos but while snorkeling (and I know to keep camera under 43 feet-but then again who can snorkel dive that deep-certainly not I) at a depth of less than 5 feet deep it filled with water.  Now I have to send it in, lost all the photos I took and won't have a camera for family reunion!

Reviews.Title: Great camera!!!
Reviews.Author: Kugelspritzer
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera for a trip to Jamaica with the thought of snorkeling/water sports.  Well I ended up using it during a scuba class down to 40 feet.  No problems and great pictures and video.  I took it to it's near maximum recommended depth of 43 feet two days in a row for thirty to forty minutes each dive, no problems.  I think it's a great little camera!

Reviews.Title: Rugged enough for kids and tough enough for my adventures
Reviews.Author: Mark Trenden "Tech Maven"
Reviews.Content: This is a great camera. I own an older and non-rugged lumix camera and love so many features about it that I had to upgrade to this. I was a professional photographer/camera-man for about 8 years and worked around the world with $80,000 cinema cameras and lately I find me leaving my DSLR cameras at home and I'm using my iPhone and smaller point and shoot cameras more and more. While this won't match a DSLR I love its relatively compact size and the fact its designed for abuse.I took this on a recent canyoneering trip where I spent hours swimming in flooded slot canyons and squeezing through tight passages. This held up through the abuse just fine. I had it handing from one of the shoulder straps on my pack and because it was lighter and more manageable than a DSLR, I was able to get more impromptu shots than I could with another camera.The screen is incredibly bright and the user interface is simple and easy to use even while I was wearing thick neoprene gloves. While I wish I could take this diving, I won't because it isn't designed for that but for all other adventures, I'll keep this in my pack. I can also let my kids use it without worrying too much due to its rugged nature.

Reviews.Title: Great camera!
Reviews.Author: John Fortino "John F"
Reviews.Content: I have several Panasonic point-and-shoot cameras DMC-TZ5 (last CCD camera), DMC-ZS19(Nice zoom, feel like it lost detail/quality moving from CCD to CMOS sensor) I wanted a durable, waterproof camera that takes QUALITY pictures (I have a junky point and shoot Fuji xp10 = terrible pictures and lousy controls). I am not planning on scuba diving with it or climbing Mt. Everest, but I will be taking it on vacations (cruise, DisneyWorld, beach). Sure will be nice not to have to worry about saltwater, sand, rain, banging it around a bit during these trips.Initial impressions, VERY nice quality pictures. Rich colors and contrast, even in lower light conditions. It appears to be a bit better quality than my DMC-ZS19, and more like the quality I had been used to on the CCD DMC-TZ5. I plan on stacking them all up and taking comparison shots. The video is super nice and I have not noticed the "noise" some have mentioned during recording. Again, plan on doing serious comparisons between all 3 cameras.Not taking any stars away for the 4.6x zoom (it IS what it IS) vs 10x+. I have read reviews where people complain it ONLY has the 4.6x zoom, YOU KNEW THAT WHEN YOU BOUGHT IT, DON'T COMPLAIN ABOUT IT! That's about 3/3rd's dumb! It would be different if it advertised 4.6x zoom but only got 2.5x or something....The wi-fi controls are COOL! I can see the image on my Android to take a family photo and take the guess out of it. It also works on video too!The GPS is a nifty function, but glad it can be turned off to save battery life. I personally could do with out it, or I would have gotten the DMC-ZS20 instead of the ZS19 (only difference is the GPS feature). You will/can crank through batteries (ESPECIALLY shooting videos) and recommend ordering extra batteries (B00CIVVT04 and maybe a "floatie" (Olympus 202204 STRAP FLOAT ORANGE if you plan on taking it in water (ocean, lake, pond, kiddie pool, etc).I got the Samsung 64GB card for this camera (B009SK57IS for several reasons. The card is FAST which is good because the camera is a 16.1 MP camera, the card is large capacity (again the camera is 16.1 MP) and I do not want to have to change the card often, or at all if it can be helped. And the card is durable, even able to withstand water (Hint, hint).Obviously, only time will tell. But initially the quality appears to be a solid build. I plan I using a silicone-friendly, waterproof lube for the gasket hatch to ensure no water leakage and margin of error with dirt.

Reviews.Title: GREAT vacation camera!
Reviews.Author: rfc
Reviews.Content: If you are looking for a worry free camera to take on trips look no further.  I consider myself a "prosumer" I own and use high end camera and lenses but keep this camera handy for times when I dont want to carry heavy equiptment bags or wouldnt dare take out an expensive camera.Positives:1. Rugged, (not indestructable) but it can handle some abuse, small drops, water.  Hand it to you kids and just hope they dont loose it.2. Portable, Stick it in you pocket and you have a much better camera than your phone offers.3. Take it swimming, snorkling, skiing.  Use in the rain without fear.4. Plenty of manual settings and options.5. Good battery life - I used it on multiple dives, with flash and video.6. Waterproof case (sold seperate) makes it waterproof for Scuba (and virtually indestructable) http://www.amazon.com/Panasonic-DMW-MCFT5-Marine-Digital-Cameras/dp/B00BZMVX26/Negatives:1. GPS / Wifi on will chew up battery2. Charges require a seperate wire (silly since this should be portable - charge should plug directly into the wall)3. NOT recommended for salt water -  I think Lumix is playing it safe here, rinse it properly and I haven't had any problems4. Maybe too many controlsOverall I recommend this camera for anyone going on vacation, its battery will last all day, you can moderately abouse it, drop it, get it wet. Picture quality is as expected for a compact (better than phone/less than DSLR), pocket friendly, addition of a waterproof case is great for divers.

Reviews.Title: Great Camera
Reviews.Author: Cyndi Smith
Reviews.Content: Before I bought this camera I did a lot of research which included asking my sister in law who is an avid traveler.  She had an older version of this camera and she loves it.  I was able to see the photo's she took with it in a variety of conditions and they came out beautifully.I'm very happy with this purchase. I spent a bit more than I planned to spend on it but it was worth it.  I bought it before we went on a trip where I knew I would be snorkeling & doing a crystal cave tour.  The cave tour was on a tube in water with very little light and the pictures came out beautifully.  Some area's of the cave were almost pitch black and the camera would rapid fire 5 pictures at a time.The camera also worked beautifully while snorkeling.  I got beautiful pictures of the sea life, corals, & etc.  The pictures were clear and well lit.This camera is shockproof & etc. but I always care for cameras gently.  I keep it in a case at all times when not in use.  It is a durable camera but due to its price I treat it with TLC.I read a variety of reviews  on this camera and I haven't had any of the problems with it that were mentioned in the negative reviews.

Reviews.Title: panasonic still having issues with water
Reviews.Author: andrei stefan
Reviews.Content: Bought it, liked it well enough, although pic quality is nothing to brag about. used it for one week, then for no apparent reason the flash seemed to have died, and every time I tried to take a pic that used the flash, the camera would jst freeze and need to be turned off and on again for any buttons to work. I worked fine in light and when the auto decided it didn't need a flash, but the flash was too much for it to handle I guess. I returned it and got my money back.I owned the previous model, the TS3, and just out of warranty it had some water damage as was apparently all to common to Panasonic's "waterproof" cameras. when I returned it to panasonic, they asked me for 330$ to replace the damaged chip. Ridiculous, since a brand new TS3 at that point was 250$!

Reviews.Title: Not waterproof!
Reviews.Author: Adam Fine
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera for my brother who was going to a beach resort on his honeymoon. After just the first day of water use the camera got a few water droplets inside the lens and screen. It seems to have a leak somewhere near the lens because when you shake it water comes out the side of it. Sadly he's not just out of a camera but also of pictures of his honeymoon... Do not buy this product!

Reviews.Title: Great work camera
Reviews.Author: Chris "Chris"
Reviews.Content: I use a camera all day, every day, for work.  I maintain foreclosed properties, and have to take pictures of everything imaginable.  In all seriousness, I probably take close to 750 pictures a day on average.  From proving work that was completed, to taking condition photos inside and out, and so on.  I have probably been through a few dozen cameras in the past five or six years.  This is my second camera from Panasonic.  Both lasting almost a year each, even with the harsh conditions.  Most could not last a month at the very best.  I can honestly say I will be hard pressed to ever change brands after using this one.  If they can continue on the path they are on.  This camera is great in low light, great shutter speed, great on battery life, great auto mode, so on and so on.  It is a great all in one camera.  May not be a "Professional" camera, but I feel it is THE best reasonably priced All in One camera on the market today.

Reviews.Title: Beware if you ever need to use Panasonic Service.
Reviews.Author: ISMan
Reviews.Content: Beware of abysmal customer service from Panasonic.For many years, I have purchased digital cameras. etc. including this one but unfortunately, for my future purchases I will mostly exclude Panasonic from my research just because of their customer support.The same time I bought this camera (Lunix DMC-TS5A) from Amazon. I purchased a ZS30 camera directly from Panasonic since the model wasn't available at the time on Amazon. I bought two camera to take on my once-in-a-lifetime trip to Africa. After getting back and starting to sort through my photos, I realized that a good quarter of the photos showed a strange round smudge on them. In fact probably more of the photos have the same problem but is not as noticeable due to the content of the image. I had a previous panasonic camera that I stopped using a year earlier because of a similar smudge thinking that something had gotten on the inside of the lens. And now, this brand new panasonic camera was having the same problem.After a very frustrating interaction with Panasonic Customer Service, I sent it to the Panasonic Repair center in McAllen Texas. As others have noted, the only verification that it was received was due to my paying extra to USPS to have signature confirmation of its arrival.Then, weeks later, it showed up back at my address. Unlike what customer service had told me would happen. I never received any contact from the McAllen service center saying that they had received it, fixed it or even that it was being shipped back.Now just one month later. I just got back from a short weekend trip taking new photos on my "fixed" camera. Half way through the trip, the view screen on the camera started displaying strange black and white vertical lines on more than half of the screen. I kept taking photos as well as I could with only partial display available in hopes that the lines wouldn't show up on the actual photos. Once I uploaded the photos to my computer, I was glad to see in fact that the lines were not there. HOWEVER, the same round smudge mark that I had paid to get fixed was on most of the photos.I just got off the phone having talked to four people including a supervisor who all seemed to care less that I was having a problem. Telling me I should fill out the service repair request online which they nor I could get to work. And now, I am told by a supervisor (Kevin) that he will email me a mailing label to once again send it in to the void known as the Panasonic Repairs Center, 4900 George McVay Drive, Suite B12, McAllen, Texas 78503.I have yet to be emailed the mailing label which at this point may or may not come to send off my camera for another 3-4+ weeks and then hopefully someday, I'll receive a camera back that may or may not be fixed or replaced. So so frustrating!Oh! And for some reason even though I am sending it back with the same case number as previously, I have to resubmit everything in the original box with a copy of my original order which was purchased directly from Panasonic since the camera for some reason never had the serial number engraved on the actual device.Well, I guess I'll try posting this on multiple review sites to hopefully help others steer clear if they think they'll ever have to deal with Panasonic's Repair *Non*Service.

Reviews.Title: Ready for summer adventure with the Lumix TS5!
Reviews.Author: James S. McGregor "Jim"
Reviews.Content: Over the last several years I have been a hardcore Canon man (point and shoot only).  I've never been into DLSR's as I like to travel light on my adventures and a point-and-shoot works better for that.  Recently the GoPro Hero3 has been getting a lot of buzz and it got me thinking about getting a newer camera with better video and camera resolution.  I have several outdoor adventures planned for this summer and so I wanted to upgrade before the season so that I could capture all the memories in higher resolution.  I did a lot of research into the GoPro Hero3 and studied its amazon ratings and reviews carefully.  The mixed reviews and troubles with the hero3 firmware led me to another possibility.  A ruggedized, waterproof point-and-shoot.There were several features of the GoPro that I really liked: - Waterproof, weatherproof - Remote control via Smartphone app - Video quality - Ability to mount in a variety of waysI began to research the leading ruggedized camera offerings and found the Lumix TS5 which has barely been released.  As of this review, there were only 2 reviews for it on Amazon and only a few CES 2013 videos on YouTube.  I searched Twitter and found more info and actual field video footage from Europe where it looks like a few guys got their hands on the camera early.  I took a chance and ordered the camera and received it last Thursday (4/11).The Lumix TS5 came with the features I really wanted, particularly the Smartphone remote control capability and GPS tagging.  The reason I wanted the remote control is so that I can mount the camera to my bike helmet and be able to start/stop the video recording without having to remove my helmet first.  I also wanted a good upgrade in video quality from my current Canon.  The GPS tagging is a bonus and I used to do that manually by keeping my camera clock in sync with GPS time and then later correlating the timestamps to determine position when the photo was taken.  Now I don't have to worry about it.So far my impressions of using the Lumix TS5 for a few days is favorable.  I was a little worried about the menu interface going from Canon to Panasonic, but I have found the menu system to be very easy to navigate and haven't had an frustrations.  I was able to set all the major functions up without having to refer to the manual.I am using the Panasonic Image App with my AT&T; Samsung Galaxy S3 and it works well with the camera.  I have tested the remote control functions and haven't had any issues with connecting the phone to the camera via WiFi.The GPS tagging works well and the GPS receiver seems to quickly acquire and maintain signal.  After I imported my first test images to Picasa, I was pleased to see that Picasa automatically brought up the Google map view of the photo location.  The Panorama feature will also come in handy as I usually create panorama images manually using Microsoft ICE.I can't yet talk about the battery life as I haven't had the camera long enough to really field test it on a weekend adventure (ATV, hiking, etc).  My guess is that the GPS and WiFi will really eat up the battery life and I am already anticipating the need for more than one battery on an excursion.  I have been looking closely at the Wasasbi batteries and am waiting for them to come out with a model compatible with the TS5.  Again, the TS5 has barely been released and so there isn't a lot out there yet.I bought the Professional Mini-Ball Head Camera Mount ([...]) and bolted it to my bike helmet.  I then mounted the TS5 to the helmet and used the smartphone app to remote control the camera.  My intention is to be able to capture footage of mountain biking in Moab this summer.  Check out my youtube videos.  Just search for alpha1145.

Reviews.Title: Take it anywhere
Reviews.Author: A K
Reviews.Content: On the advice of a friend I recently purchased the Panasonic Lumix DMC-TS5A16.1MP Tough digital camera.  I took it with me on a dive trip to Bonaire.The intelligent features of this camera made it very useful above and below the water.  In the automatic mode in would detect back-lighting and take multiple exposures to integrate for the optimal exposure of foreground and background features.  The auto-focus was a bit fussy in low-light conditions with an in-experienced operator.  If time isn't allowed for the camera to properly sense some low-light pictures at dinner were out of focus.The battery held up well.  I purchased a back-up with a plug-in wall charger that worked well from Big Mike on amazon.I used it for shallow dives (typically second dive of the day).  Keeping my depth to less than 35 feet, I put the camera into advanced underwater mode and set the flash to always on and got some really amazing pictures.  It really captured the vivid colors of fish, corals, and my dive buddy.  The water clarity in Bonaire contributed to easily getting great pictures.  On one night dive when the water was very turbid only my macro shots looked good.  I could typically get into small areas that those with larger cameras could not and take some "blind" shots to try and get some fish hiding in the coral.  At the macro level I could get shots to within 8-12 inches that would remain in focus.  One curious fish came within 6 inches of the lens and I could not keep him in focus.  The best part was that I could put the camera on a retractable cord attached to my BC and just let it fall if I needed to use my hands.  I typically kept it in my BC pocket when entering and exiting the water.  I did have to be cautious to make sure the retractable cord did not become entangled with my Reg/Octo.  On deck I stored it in a waterproof otter box 3000 to protect it from heavy gear.It seems to feature some good stop action as well.  I was able to use it while skiing to capture great images of the kids taking some jumps under good lighting conditions.The wifi was a little difficult to figure out at first. But, I was able to directly transfer my images to my iPad after getting it set up.  First, I downloaded the Panasonic Image App for my iPad. When you turn on the wifi for the camera there is an option for direct connect.  I used this and then in my iPad settings I connected to the wifi sent from the camera and entered the passcode.  The camera then detected the direct connection with the iPad and instructed to open the Panasonic Image app.  Opening the app allowed initially does not appear to connect to the camera if one is looking at the iPad.  But, on the camera I was able to manually select multiple images (a bit tedious) and then send them to the iPad. While the iPad seemed to be still searching, the camera began uploading the images which wen t very quickly.  Once the images were uploaded the iPad prompted to view the images.  The images were then available to any of the apps I was using to view pictures on the iPad.  Overall, a very cool feature that allowed me to directly transfer images via wifi sent directly from the camera when no other wifi was available.  You can also save the connection as a favorite on the camera to speed up the process in the future.  You need to set the iPad wifi to the camera generated signal in order to transfer directly if the iPad is detecting multiple wifi sources.Stepwise: Download Panasonic Image app to iPad.1. Turn on camera wifi2. click New Connection3. click Send images stored in camera4. click Smartphone5. click Direct6. click Manual Connection7. In iPad wifi settings, set iPad wifi to SSID sent by camera and enter password provided by camera8. When camera indicates Wifi connection complete, open the Panasonic Image App as prompted by camera9. Camera will prompt to connect to iPad10. Camera indicates connection completed. click menu/set on camera11. Option to send single or multiple images. click multi12. tab through images using up/down/left/right keys. Select images by using DISP. button to select/deselect.13. click menu/set to send images14. camera indicates "proceed time" (yes/no),  click yes15. images begin uploading16. iPad prompts to review images once fully uploaded.Save the connection as a favorite on the camera to speed up the process in the future.I found this feature very useful since I didn't bring my PC and wanted to review/share images daily.Overall, I highly recommend this camera.

Reviews.Title: Clicking during video recording - not acceptable
Reviews.Author: Michael A. Hightchew
Reviews.Content: I was really excited when I received the camera yesterday.  I played with a lot of the features of the camera.  Had a little difficulty getting it to sync with my Iphone 4 but not too bad.  All was fine until I recorded a 10 second clip of my daughter.  I played it back to my wife to show her how good the video looked.  For three times during that 10 seconds there is a very noticeable clicking noise during playback.  I assume it's picking up something in the camera while recording.  I played the clip thru my tv and took the card out and copied the file onto my computer.  All 3 way have the irritating sound.  Just saw Mr. Cohen's exact comments for this product.  Buyer beware!!

Reviews.Title: Absolutely Awesome Camera!
Reviews.Author: middlesister#
Reviews.Content: We purchased this camera in anticipation of a two-week trip to Tahiti, and it is flawless as well as extremely easy to operate. We routinely used it at depths between 2-10 feet of water, however it is rated for approximately 27-30 feet. The picture quality and color were phenomenal, and the video footage we achieved was priceless on what we believe to be a once-in-a-lifetime trip!

Reviews.Title: Great underwater camera
Reviews.Author: M. Guericke "reckless37"
Reviews.Content: I took this on a recent trip to the Dominican Republic. It was great going in the ocean and hiking in waterfalls. The GPS worked very well, but does take a little while to lock sometimes. I used the trail function one day, then uploaded the file to an online site to decode it, and it worked great. I haven't done much with the wi-fi, it does seem to be not the best feature.I'm happy with the quality of the photos, both underwater (close range) and normal.It has a lot of fun features, many of which I haven't fully utilized so far :)

Reviews.Title: Waterproof failed after a couple uses 2nd day of Mayan Riviera trip
Reviews.Author: J. Solberg
Reviews.Content: this camera definitely takes excellent video and photos underwater, while it remains waterproof. I tested it in the bathtub (OK, admit it, you would too when you bring it home for the first time)then I took about five minutes of incredible video of trout in the river during a fly-fishing trip in the Rockies, then off to the Mayan Riviera, where it failed the second time i took it into the water.I followed directions to the letter regarding care, but poof.While it worked, it was excellent.Now I am preparing for another trip to the carribean, and am myself pondering what camera to bring.

Reviews.Title: Good for Point and Shoot All Weather fun
Reviews.Author: Bri
Reviews.Content: I purchased this for my wife to use for her dog training videos. It takes pretty decent point-and-click photos. The video is pretty sharp as well. The only hang up with it is the Wi-Fi connectivity. There are some issues with connecting and downloading through it's Wi-Fi with an iPhone.

Reviews.Title: A very nice all around pocket camera.
Reviews.Author: S. W. Conley
Reviews.Content: I bought this as a backup for vacation to the TS1 we had.My daughters also have TS1 and TS3's.All of them perform well although the TS5 has more features obviously.We have used all of them numerous times for snorkeling and had no issue following the given directions.The TS1 I bought this for backup for was over three years old and failed to turn on at the very beginning of the vacation - so I was glad I had the backup.  It had been used just the week before and had no been in water  in more than 4 months.It turns out that it had circuit board failure and had had no water damage at all.  So the seals were still good after three years even on the TS1.  The TS5 is suppose to have better seals - and it looks like it does.Thee number of features is way to many to mention and the Videos taken with it are spectacular.As with ALL pocket cameras - it does have noise issues at high ISOs - so you need a flash or good light or be prepared to have a bit of noise.  The stabilization though is VERY good.In general, the camera's Intelligent mode is so good that I leave it there 90% of the time.  And that is coming from a DSLR owner with two DSLRs and 5 lens - who NEVER uses the DSLR's on AUTO.  Because their "auto" is no where near as good as Panasonic's Intelligent mode.

Reviews.Title: The reviews are right- great camera!
Reviews.Author: Gary Falco
Reviews.Content: I just came back from a week long trip to Mexico, and I brought the camera.  The pictures are very good quality, and the waterproof feature allows you to use just one camera all trip long.  The best feature for snorkeling is the photo blast option.  It snaps a number of pictures in just a second, which almost guarantees that you will get a great angle or pose from whatever you were trying to get a picture of.  Pictures at night also came out pretty well, and that is a peeve of mine with most other cameras.  I did the research before I purchased this camera and I'm so glad I got it.

Reviews.Title: Dust on Sensor bad service
Reviews.Author: SteveS
Reviews.Content: Got dust on the sensor in a couple of months, for a water proof and dust proof unit was disappointed. I buy two of these cameras for work every 1-2 yearsI sent this in for service 3 weeks ago and Panasonic was going to call me back and never did, also they had no idea when I would get it or the status of the unit.The image quality is ok, slow at time to capture the image, poor low light capability. I was going to purchase a Panasonic mirrorless unit, but after this I think I'll look at another manufacturer. I have purchased 6 of these for my business and this was the last one.

Reviews.Title: Panasonic Lumix DMC-TS5S 16.1 MP Tough Digital Camera with 9.3x Intelligent...
Reviews.Author: Ghassan Alzamil
Reviews.Content: one of the best Camera I ever had ,, especially I used it for diving and it was perfect , and very clear under water.

Reviews.Title: opportunities missed...& poor audio
Reviews.Author: A. Lowell "lowella"
Reviews.Content: They focused on putting maps on the camera, filling up the onboard storage etc...but changed the batteries (AGAIN) and cable (AGAIN) with little quality improvement over the last few. I loved my early rugged lumix...we'll see if this holds up. The early one didn't but I really put it to the test...P.S. I sent it back today. I have the clicking/grinding on all video as well. :(

Reviews.Title: Great Ruggedised Camera
Reviews.Author: mjackl
Reviews.Content: We had one of the previous models of this camera which broke when we took it too deep underwater. This model allows you to go much deeper than past models. Pictures and video quality are great. Lots of settings and options for more advanced users, but still very simple interface for the average user.

Reviews.Title: Panasonic Lumix DMC-TS5D
Reviews.Author: Peter Tothpal
Reviews.Content: Likeness -Practical, fun, easy to use camera. I like that I don't have to worry in the rain.Nice color capture , great under water pix!Dislike -More you zoom in,  looses sharpness.

Reviews.Title: I recommend this products
Reviews.Author: Enrique Delaveau
Reviews.Content: I am very happy with my camera, i use it every weekend whitewater kayaking, taking a very very large quantity of the videos and photos in very cold and rough conditions.I chose this among others because this can record in 60FPS (so you can make slo motions video after), i have followed the instructions (cleaning the battery door), and it has worked perfectly, not a single drop of water inside the camera.

Reviews.Title: rugged
Reviews.Author: michael goldstein
Reviews.Content: used the camera underwater down to 25 ft. and it worked fine.  it also survived abuse during a 4 week adventurous trip to Belize.design limits optical zoom, but that's what you sacrifice for the ruggedness.  pocket size made it convenient to carry everywhere.

Reviews.Title: Tough Enough
Reviews.Author: L. Munson
Reviews.Content: Oregon coast + 75 mph gusts with rain and blowing sand = good pictures. I was snapping pics of the crashing surf in the middle of a Pacific storm hitting the coast and this camera was a champ.

Reviews.Title: Very Impressive camera and it's waterproof too!
Reviews.Author: Ramsey "Would rather be living in Costa Rica"
Reviews.Content: I first have to tell you that I'm a camera addict and supply my friends with cameras when we travel or go out together. So with that said I will compare this camera to others that I have.I have compared this camera to the Olympus TG-2 ihs, Olympus TG1-1 ihs, Sony HDR-AS30 and the Sony TX200v plus a Sony DSC-rx100 (not waterproof)This Panasonic takes great pictures! I'm talking about a camera that can safely be stored in and taken in and out of you pocket. It's nice to take anywhere with you and this way you'll get those great pictures you have been missing. Even in dim locations or poor lighting I was very impressed with the level of detail I was getting. The Sony RX100 still blows this camera out of the water... and must remain away from water so it will less action of coarse. But I now keep the rx100 nearby stored in a water proof case (pelican 1010 case) and use the DMC-TS5 (FT5) for everyday fun.So next time we go out I will keep this camera for myself!

Reviews.Title: My 2nd Lumix camera, takes great photos but some of the changes in this model are incredibly stupid.
Reviews.Author: Rick the TR6 guy
Reviews.Content: I liked my last Lumix and had it about three years. That camera got some bad press because of leaking problems. I never had ANY leaking issues (and generally wasn't super careful with it when I took it in the water) and thought that it was a great camera.This camera's description reads very well and makes it sound like a super camera, which it is in many ways.  I've had it about a year. Pictures are great, works well underwater and has many bells and whistles, many of which are difficult to implement, like transferring photos via Bluetooth.However, my main gripes with this camera are simple things which irritate me all the time:1/ The battery charger.  They went from a very compact design to a larger one with a cord.  The other one was easy to bring along on vacation, this one is just another unnecessary added burden to my electronics bag.2/ The USB cord for transferring photos.  It's now way too short. Camera has to sit on the floor when I'm transferring photos. Granted, I'll usually just pop out the SD card but that doesn't always work as well when I have to use the dubious Photostudio software to clear out the camera.3/ Burst mode is sketchy.  Maybe other cameras are like this too but I don't want umpteen different "burst" folders after I've transferred my photos.I would not buy this camera again but will likely continue to use it for a while.

Reviews.Title: Safe all use camera!
Reviews.Author: b.coñ
Reviews.Content: Great for swimming pools or not deep in the ocean/ so its also great at making it thru bad weather... How many cameras could be dropped into a mud puddle and still be fine!

Reviews.Title: Great pocket sized camera.
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer
Reviews.Content: An amazingly versatile camera. I've taken it snorkeling, mountain climbing, sailing, etc. Had it pulled off over my head in a river kayaking, but my attached float saved it. Full of cool features, and can operate remotely with your smartphone or iPad.

Reviews.Title: Camera works great, but be careful with the download connectors.
Reviews.Author: Aaron M. Baum
Reviews.Content: Takes great pictures dry and in the water.  Easy to switch between stills and movies.  Panoramic setting creates amazing landscapes.  Seems very rugged.The one issue I have is that the HDMI and the A/V output (they don't call it USB in the manual) connectors look very similar.  They are not marked in any way on the camera, so you have to look in the manual to find out which is which.  If you don't and you try plugging the A/V out cable into the HDMI connector on the camera (yes, it will fit quite easily), you will damage the HDMI connector (speaking from experience).Other than that, I had no problems with the camera.  Snorkled to depths of 20ft or so and never had any issues with leaking,

Reviews.Title: Great camera for the beach
Reviews.Author: Barbara Steinman "Cat Pillow"
Reviews.Content: Sharp pictures, easy to use, good underwater pictures. Pictures have GPS information so I know exactly where I took them. There is an automatic setting for beach/underwater pictures.  It works well and the pictures are sharp. I get fairly good detail shooting fish underwater, though colors in underwater photos seem a bit too green to me. I use it in the Gulf of Mexico while standing or swimming in water about waist to chest deep. I take photos of sea life and shore birds. Colors in photos taken in air are vibrant and true to life.The only problem I've had is difficulty is seeing what is on the screen when in bright sunlight, though it's much easier to see than with my older Nikon underwater camera this replaced.I would recommend attaching the camera to some kind of a float before taking it in water just to make sure you don't lose it.  I use a Chums Waterproof Camera Float.

Reviews.Title: Great point-and-shoot Waterproof Camera
Reviews.Author: Rich
Reviews.Content: I have had this camera for 3 months now. It replaced my prior Panasonic Waterproof camera that was stolen on vacation.  That camera was great, and this is even better.Let's start off with the main issues.  I'm so tired of people that pay for these small point-and-shoot cameras and then complain about picture quality.  This camera takes very solid pictures. Is it a professional camera? Of course not.  If you want that - then spend your huge $$ for a large camera that won't fit in your pocket and won't go in a pool.Besides solid pictures, the camera has a lot of size/quality settings for photo and video, and has a fairly quick trigger.  The interface is easy to use, and you pop the SD card in the computer to transfer your pictures.  The battery has been fine.  There is built in Wi-Fi which is pretty cool for uploading pictures off the camera on the fly (for backup, e-mail, Facebook etc)..  I must admit this was a bit challenging to set up, but once it was set up, it has been fine.If I had any complaint, its a very minor one that should never deter anyone from buying this camera - the battery charging.  You have to remove the battery, and you have to use a charging unit that is a unit plus a cord.  Compared to prior Panasonic cameras, this is a step backwards.  Other cameras let you charge the battery right in the camera with the USB cable, and I've also seen the charger unit as a self-contained wall-plug-in type.  Not sure why this camera doesn't have either of those.  Again, really not a big deal, but figured I'd mention it.This is a great camera with great features for the price point.  It has all the essentials for this type of camera.

Reviews.Title: Great Photos! Playback is slow. Wifi requires a compter genius I guess.
Reviews.Author: Mike1979
Reviews.Content: I bought this for a trip to Hawaii and it worked great! The photos came out fantastic and the burst mode allowed us to get some great action shots. We never had any problems with the water. We swam in the ocean, in the pool and even jumped of clifs with it. Soaked it in some fresh water at the end of the day and left it open to dry completly while the battery recharged. I only have three dislikes. 1) The battey charger comes with a long cord, not simply a plug-in box. One more cord to stuff in the luggage! 2) Reviewing the photos takes a awhile. Once you hit the "play" button it takes a fews seconds to come up. And even worse if you want to immediately zoom or view pictures other than the most recent photo, you have to wait for it to process all the photos into memory. As the card got more full this was taking 1-2 minutes. 3) Could not get my iPhone to sync up with the camera. Followed the directions to the "T" and no luck. (oh well, I'd rather put the card in the laptop anyhow)

Reviews.Title: Works as Advertised if Not better!
Reviews.Author: Timothy Cheng
Reviews.Content: This Camera solved my problems! Rated best "T O U G H" Camera of 2013 for a reason. Went on a 7 night cruise to Bermuda, took underwater pictures and minutes of video in HD and 16 MP Shots From Clear Underwater photos to HD underwater video, this camera works like a dream. No one had a camera like me! Everyone asked about my Camera and its capabilities, even took photos for strangers that I had met and became friends with them since I could take pictures during our kayaking excursion with my cameras waterproof capabilities. No other camera has an AUTO INTELLIGENT mode like this one! It chooses the best setting for you no matter what the conditions are from Bright and Sunny to Dark and Stormy! Remote shooting with your smartphone is amazing too! You don't have to ask strangers to take your pictures for you! Just set up your camera and use your own cell phone to pre-screen your photo......smile.......and CAPTURE! Works like a charm! Best investment for the money! Well Worth Every Penny. Highly Recommended! Will try the NFC technology when I obtain a few NFC enabled Devices!, Stay Tuned for Updates!

Reviews.Title: This is exactly what I needed!
Reviews.Author: Davee L. Sarim
Reviews.Content: This camera takes beautiful pictures! And of course the good thing about it is that you can take it under water with you. I've used it for snorkeling a couple of times and it did the job. The only thing is that when it is underwater the pictures aren't as good... But other than that it's what i've been looking for for a while. It's pretty bulky but I guess that's a good thing since it's suppose to be "Tough" and I've dropped it a few times and nothing was wrong with it. I would recommend if you are looking for a camera that can go under water with you and not have to worry about a case.

Reviews.Title: A Little Disappointing
Reviews.Author: Iainsmith
Reviews.Content: I just bought the Lumix TS5A for a trip to Glacier Park, MT and have mixed feelings about the camera. I did quite a bit of research using both Consumer Reports ratings and Amazon reviews before deciding on the Lumix. I planned to do some rafting and wanted a waterproof and rugged camera. I had a great photo opp when we ran into a large grizzly bear. The Lumix took good video but the photos were so grainy that they resemble impressionist paintings. The Lumix doesn't come with a case so I used a Canon case to protect the display screen as I'd read that it scratches easily. It does! I'm surprised that a ruggedized camera has a display that scratches so easily. Despite great care I now have 2 big scratches in the display. The basic camera operation is quite easy but if you want to use any of the more advanced features it's not very intuitive. I wan't able to get the WiFi or NFC working despite a few tries. Lastly, every time I turn on the camera it asks if I want to display the underwater use requirements even though the manuals says it will only ask once. I hope after getting used to the Lumix I can give it a better review.

Reviews.Title: Great Camera Worked Great!!
Reviews.Author: Chewieaz
Reviews.Content: Used it to capture the kids first time in the ocean. The camera worked great. The only have 2 gripes.1) In quiet locations the microphones pick up the sound of the image stabilization mechanism and it can be heard on the recordings.  It is a still camera that you can take some videos with so it doesn't shock me. This is a common problem across the industry. If this is a major concern a full blown video camera might be a better option.2) The WiFi is clunky to set up and needs some refinement to make it easier to use.  I looked at other cameras with WiFi capabilities on the market and found that although it is not perfect it is the most user friendly. This is definitely a new area for manufacturers and it will probably take a coupe more iteration to get things completely dialed in.

Reviews.Title: Great camera
Reviews.Author: Bill Hamilton
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera for a hiking trip. Not only is it durable and compact, it captures natural colors well. The panoramic feature was great for capturing wide vistas. The only limitation is the extent of the zoom.

Reviews.Title: Love this camera!!!
Reviews.Author: Kiowa Cav
Reviews.Content: Love this camera.  I took it on a cruise vacation while familiarizing myself with the users manual while in the plane ride on the way to the port.  When used as dirrected this camera is capable of taking some of the most colorful and vibrant pictures in and out of the water.  The zoom and clarity are impressive for a tough-camera and the boldness of the colors that it can capture are fantastic.  Unlike other users I have not detected a "ticking" in the playback of recorded video and had no difficulty with this function or the "moving picture" feature as well.  The battery life seems a bit short, but if functions such as the bluetooth and GPS are disabled, the battery life is comparable to standard digital cameras with no loss of "picture taking" attributes.  I have used this camera in the air, on the ground, on the beach in the sand, and both in and around fresh and salt water to depths of up to 20 feet (and even face-to-face with a shark) and its function was flawless and pictures clear (granted the shakyness of my hand while being confronted by the shark was a bit too much for even the stabilization lens of the camera).  Great buy.  I would highly recommend.

Reviews.Title: Rugged Camera with nice features...
Reviews.Author: MP "Small Business Owner"
Reviews.Content: I did want to let people know my thinking on why I purchased this over the TG-2. Initial reaction is positive - easy set up and configuration, decent picture quality in both stills and video.** Update - picture quality is good and video mode on the beach worked well.  Easily cleaned up and didn't worry about taking it in the water. **Let me first state that this and the other waterproof cameras are not a DSLR cameras, so you should not expect great pictures that you could enlarge while maintaining quality.  So, if that is what you are used to, I suggest you try out some other point and shoot cameras before purchasing.  This is a rugged, take anywhere camera, so some things will have to give to protect the lens.1. Wi-Fi - Standard feature - easily transfer pictures and control device remotely through Image App on your smartphone.  In addition, allows for wi-fi updates of gps assist data. Your options are wifi direct (camera to phone) or wifi through access point.2. GPS Assist Data - lasts 30 days versus the TG-2's 14 days and can be updated through any wi-fi connection (i.e. public hotspots).  No need to use special software or connect to your computer like the TG-2 requires.3. Charger - Battery is charged outside of the camera unlike the TG-2 which may seem like a negative until you factor in the charge time while you are on vacation.  You will probably want to keep a second battery on hand and will need/want a separate charger unless you are not going to be using he camera during the charging process.  I can state on my last vacation, I had a battery charging while I used my other camera during the day.  You do not want to miss a snorkeling shot because you ran out of juice.  The TG-2 uses a special USB connector and if you want to charge outside of the camera, you need to purchase a special USB charger.4. Video - TS5 offers 1080p/60 for video so eliminates some of the choppiness. Yes, you do hear the focusing of the camera, but only in quiet locations.  If you are filming outside, it shouldn't be an issue.I think those are the major reasons/differences for right now and I will update more about the most important factor - picture quality after I use it a bit more.  However, you need to keep in mind what I said above regarding picture quality if you are used to DSLR quality.More to come!

Reviews.Title: Clicking noise during video recording easily reproduced
Reviews.Author: PC
Reviews.Content: UPDATED:so i received a replacement camera from Amazon and the clicking noise is still there, easily reproduced as stated below, but the noise is slightly less and more muffled.  The first camera noise was more like flicking a glass noise and this new camera is more like tapping fingers on a wood desk.  Again in 1080p MP4 mode 30fps the noise is barely noticeable but in 1080p AVCHD 60fps it is very loud, especially when filming in low light conditions.  I believe this is a design flaw.Be in iA (intelligent auto) modeselect the AVCHD 1080p 60fps recording modemake sure Continuous AF autofocus is enabledbe in a darker room so the iA mode will enter into the candlelight high sensitivity modebe in a quiet environmentthe clicking noise seems to happen whenever the autofocus has to work, and it is particularly loud when having to work with this 1080p 60fps recording modethe noise is much less when recording in 1080p 30fps MPEG mode, i have no idea whythis problem seems to exist across numerous devices so i urge people to call into the Panasonic help line 800-211-7262 and open a ticket.  It only took me 10 minutes and they apparently do not have a history of anyone complaining about this issue so we need to make them aware!maybe they can fix it with a firmware update, but until then i am returning this the noise is too much it ruins the video mode

Reviews.Title: not an upgrade
Reviews.Author: fishy "know it all"
Reviews.Content: wifi works great and good battery life. picture and video quality were not as good as my sony tx100. also as stated here in another review the onboard mics pick up constant grinding from the autofocus

Reviews.Title: LOVE THIS CAMERA
Reviews.Author: C. Starr
Reviews.Content: Bought it for a cruise to the Caribbean and wanted to be able to have the camera with us all the time, in and out of the water.  All the pictures came out great.  Awesome video and underwater shots were exactly what I had hoped for.  Wish the outer lens had an auto cleaning mechanism because when you come up out of the water and take shots, there is sometimes water on the lens and thus water spots on images.  I am getting better to remember to wipe it real quick before shooting above water level pictures.

Reviews.Title: Great Features....poor power
Reviews.Author: Norma J. Ramey "AbbyNL"
Reviews.Content: This is my second Lumix camera.  The features in this DMC-TS5D are a definitely upgraded and easy to understand. What has me scratching my head is the old school power supply.  It does have a small battery but the charger is old school.  Instead of building the charger with a direct plug it has a cord to plug-in.  Another cord to keep up with is not something I think is an upgrade to match the other features of the camera.  I probably not keep this long.

Reviews.Title: You can trust this one!
Reviews.Author: ChillinVillan
Reviews.Content: I can't even begin to tell you how many reviews I read for different digital underwater cameras.  I took a couple of months to really do my research...and it paid off.  This camera is amaaaaazing.  Took it to Belize for a vacation- used it for a full day snorkeling trip.  We were in and outta the water all day- the camera did NOT fail.  It was trustworthy, took awesome underwater pictures and was easy to use.  Just read the simple directions for underwater use and you can't go wrong.  Outside of the water, it was also fantastic!  Beautiful pictures of mayan ruins, sunrises, sunsets, beach scenes, wildlife...the list goes on.  We even got impressive night pictures of the moon reflecting on the water which is normally not easy to do!  Use the intelligent setting OR have some fun and choose for yourself.  Lots of neat options and you can also crop and use special features (black and white, etc) on the pictures too.Another important feature that worked like a charm: the wifi!!  I was psyched that this worked so well and we were on a remote island!  Once the camera linked to my phone on its' own wifi, I was able to download the pix RIGHT TO MY PHONE with NO problems.  It took about 1/2 an hour to figure out; I'm no techie.  However, if I could figure it out, using the insert, so can you.  You can't upload directly from camera to facebook and you can't send directly from camera to email...but being able to send directly to your phone with no wires is good enough for me.You cannot beat the price for this camera.  It LOOKS really nice too!  I got mine in the blue and I bought an orange wrist floatie to go with it...that's a must have if you're taking it in the water.  On our snorkeling trip others also brought underwater cameras...one guy's failed as soon as he got in the water.  Somebody else had a cheap plastic one so you can't even see what your pix look like until developed.  Everyone loved this one and was asking where I got it from.If you check out other underwater camera reviews, there are so many in which people say that it failed once underwater.  There is only a VERY small percentage of reviewers that report this for this camera.  This may be b/c of user error- just something to consider.I highly recommend this camera.  You can't beat it!

Reviews.Title: Floats nicely
Reviews.Author: John Ross Judson
Reviews.Content: We were completely happy with this camera on our recent Hawaii vacation, particularly after having our micro 4/3 camera drop on a stone floor on day one. That meant we were down to one camera, and the Lumix worked perfectly. We were in the water a fair amount, and it performed well there. I found that setting the video mode to a lower resolution but higher frame rate (60fps) made the resulting videos look better (to me, anyway).If you're wondering about a wrist strap that can successfully float this camera, I can tell you this one works:Samsung PSF9W1E Floating Strap - Neon Green

Reviews.Title: LOve it
Reviews.Author: Maung A. Lin
